Article.ArticleTitle: [Ozone Spatial-temporal Distribution and Trend over China Since 2013: Insight from Satellite and Surface Observation].

AbstractText: Satellite and surface observed O<sub>3</sub> concentrations were applied to analyze the spatial-temporal distribution and trends of O<sub>3</sub> over China. The satellite and surface observations agree well, revealing that the highest concentrations of O<sub>3</sub> are distributed in East China, and with a seasonal pattern of high in summer and low in winter. Records of the diurnal variation of O<sub>3</sub> over the four cities of interest (Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Chengdu) reveal that O<sub>3</sub> peaked at 15:00-16:00 each day. Statistical analysis indicates that there is no significant difference in O<sub>3</sub> concentration between weekends and weekdays for the cities of Beijing, Guangzhou, and Chengdu. Surface O<sub>3</sub> over China increased dramatically from April 2013 to June 2018. The increase of the surface O<sub>3</sub> concentration from 2014 to 2017 is significant for Beijing, Shanghai, and Chengdu, and the rates of increase were 2.36, 3.3, and 3.6 μg·(m<sup>3</sup>·a)<sup>-1</sup>, respectively. Analysis based on the daily max 8 h rolling mean O<sub>3</sub> concentration reveals that the percentage of days with O<sub>3</sub> concentration exceeding the national standard (160 μg·m<sup>-3</sup>) in 2014-2017 were 17.2% for Beijing, 10.7% for Shanghai, 8.8% for Guangzhou, and 11.2% for Chengdu. O<sub>3</sub> pollution is most severe in Beijing where the highest O<sub>3</sub> concentration occurs, along with the largest number of days with daily max 8 h rolling O<sub>3</sub> concentration exceeding 160 μg·m<sup>-3</sup>.
